articles.title: Bangkok commuters to enjoy 20-baht flat fare across all electric trains
articles.summary:
Starting October 1, Bangkok commuters will pay a flat fare of 20 baht (US$0.62) for all electric train rides. This new government policy, announced by Thailand's Ministry of Finance, aims to reduce living costs for its citizens.

A budget of nearly 8 billion baht has been approved to subsidize fares for the first year. Registration for the service begins August 25 via the "Tang Rat" mobile app, requiring Thai citizens to provide their 13-digit ID. Passengers can then use credit cards, debit cards, or existing Rabbit Cards. The policy covers 13 rail lines across Bangkok and its suburbs, spanning 279.84 km and 194 stations, as part of broader efforts to lower utility and energy expenses.

Vietnam Airlines is adding over 100,000 seats, totaling 600,000 seats across nearly 2,900 flights, for the upcoming National Day holiday period from August 29 to September 3. This marks a significant increase from last year.

Domestically, the airline is boosting frequency on key routes connecting Hanoi with Ho Chi Minh City, Da Nang, Cam Ranh, Da Lat, and Hue, offering almost 418,000 seats, a 30% year-on-year rise. International capacity will also increase by 18% to nearly 177,000 seats, especially on services linking Vietnam with India, China, Thailand, and Australia.

Passengers booking tickets on specific dates (August 19, September 1, and September 2) will receive e-vouchers for Premium and Flexible Economy tickets, valid for domestic travel until February 2026.

articles.title: Singapore’s higher retirement age keeps more seniors in workforce: study
articles.summary:
A new study indicates Singapore's policy of raising retirement and re-employment ages has successfully increased senior employment rates. After 2022 hikes (retirement age from 62 to 63, re-employment from 67 to 68), affected workers saw employment rise by 0.4 and 0.7 percentage points, respectively. By 2024, 49.1% of seniors aged 65-69 were employed.

While the policy primarily delays rather than prevents seniors from leaving the workforce, its positive impact has been sustained. It particularly benefited those in knowledge-intensive roles. This strategy aims to safeguard senior workers, provide continued employment options, and address manpower needs in Singapore's rapidly aging population. Further phased increases to 65 and 70 are planned by 2030.

articles.title: 3 foreigners detained in Singapore for working illegally as delivery people
articles.summary:
Singapore has detained three foreigners for working illegally as delivery drivers, following a nationwide enforcement operation by the Ministry of Manpower. During checks on 375 workers, three were arrested, and investigations are underway for both the illegal workers and locals who facilitated them. Penalties for illegal work can include fines up to SGD20,000 and two years imprisonment.

Delivery companies like Deliveroo and Grab state they combat illegal employment and account sharing through measures like selfie verification. However, instances of account rental for illegal work still appear online. Last year, around 90 complaints about suspected illegal foreign delivery drivers were investigated, indicating an ongoing challenge despite efforts from authorities and companies.

articles.title: From hawkers to Michelin-starred, why many Singapore restaurants are shuttering
articles.summary:
Singapore's food and beverage (F&B) sector, including Michelin-starred restaurants, faces severe challenges, leading to a record 3,047 closures in 2024—the highest in nearly two decades. Key factors driving this struggle include soaring operating costs like rising rents, ingredient prices, and manpower expenses.

Additionally, changing consumer habits contribute to the downturn; Singaporeans are increasingly traveling abroad for cheaper dining options, while many are cutting back on local dining out due to economic pressures. Manpower shortages and strict foreign worker policies further compound difficulties.

Despite concerns that this trend could erode Singapore's culinary heritage, some promise remains. Growth drivers include rising tourism, new F&B establishments in mixed developments, and landlords adapting spaces. Operators are also streamlining operations, innovating concepts, and adopting technology to adapt and push for continued growth.

articles.title: 250 projects worth $48B launched to drive Vietnam's new development phase
articles.summary:
Vietnam has launched 250 projects valued at US$48.64 billion, signaling a new phase of growth. These include major investments in transport (59 projects), civil/urban, industry, and technical infrastructure, highlighted by Viettel's $10 trillion R&D Center for semiconductors and AI.

Under the "500 days and nights" campaign, Vietnam has significantly expanded its expressway and coastal road networks, with further targets for year-end. These initiatives are projected to boost national GDP by over 18% in 2025 and support ambitious growth targets of 8% in 2025 and double-digits from 2026-2030.

Healthcare is also a key focus, with 10 new projects, including a 1,000-bed oncology hospital. Vietnam aims for 90% population access to comprehensive preventive healthcare by 2030, striving for global leadership in social welfare by 2045, underpinned by rising per capita GDP.

articles.title: Conglomerate Thaco’s CEO resigns after 7 years at helm
articles.summary:
Pham Van Tai has resigned as CEO of Vietnamese conglomerate Thaco Corporation after seven years, with chairman Tran Ba Duong assuming the role concurrently. Tai's departure is voluntary, occurring during the company's group-wide restructuring and digital transformation.

Thaco, involved in automaking, agriculture, and construction, also saw senior director Nguyen Mot step down. Three new deputy CEOs were appointed: Nguyen Quang Bao (Thaco Auto), Tran Bao Son (Thaco Agri), and Nguyen Hoang Tue (Thadico). This leadership shift supports Thaco's strategy to balance experienced leaders with a young workforce for digital demands. The company plans to hire 26,400 people this year, increasing its payroll to 77,100, largely for Thaco Agri.

articles.title: Child obesity in Vietnam balloons to rich nations' rates
articles.summary:
Child obesity rates in Vietnam have more than doubled in the last decade, reaching 19% nationally and up to 26% in major cities, nearing developed nations' levels. This alarming trend is considered a "ticking time bomb" for future non-communicable diseases and a significant burden on the healthcare system.

Key causes include a modern diet high in fast food and sugar, excessive sedentary behavior among urban children, and a lack of nutritionally balanced school meals. Experts warn of rising cases of type 2 diabetes in young children. To address this, there's a strong call for legislative action, including a proposed Law on Disease Prevention, to mandate comprehensive school nutrition policies, education, and physical activity programs, aiming to build a healthier future generation.

articles.title: Foreigners take profits as market rises to new peak, sell $2B worth of stocks
articles.summary:
Foreign investors have sold $2.14 billion worth of Vietnamese stocks this year, despite the market's nearly 30% gain and all-time highs. This significant divestment, especially in August, was fueled by profit-taking after the market surged over 50% since April, a major portfolio restructuring by South Korean fund SK Investment from Vingroup, and new U.S. import tariffs. Some capital also redirected to less volatile emerging markets like Thailand and Taiwan.

Despite this, analysts are optimistic about Vietnam's future. The country's stock market is expected to be upgraded from a "frontier" to an "emerging market" by FTSE Russell, a key government objective. This upgrade is projected to attract substantial new foreign capital inflows of $3-7 billion, providing a significant boost to the market.
articles.location: Vietnam's stock market and Ho Chi Minh Exchange

articles.title: Electric sightseeing bus route launched in downtown Hanoi
articles.summary:
Hanoi has launched the E11 electric sightseeing bus route, offering free rides until the end of 2025. This new route connects key capital attractions like the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, Hoan Kiem Lake, and Thang Long Imperial Citadel.

Operated by Hanoi's Public Transport Management and Operation Center and Vinbus, the E11 route runs daily with varying frequencies, using 10 electric buses, each seating about 60 passengers.

The E11 is Hanoi's seventh electric bus route introduced in 2025, increasing the city's electric bus count to 108. It's part of Hanoi's larger plan to transition its entire bus network to electric or green energy vehicles by 2030, enhancing eco-friendly transportation and tourism.

articles.title: Passengers' transportation, transfers a concern in relocating international flights to Long Thanh
articles.summary:
VnExpress.net reports on the Airports Corporation of Vietnam's (ACV) proposal to move all international flights from Ho Chi Minh City's congested Tan Son Nhat Airport to the new Long Thanh Airport, 40km away. ACV aims to establish Long Thanh as a major regional aviation hub, consolidating international operations and enabling Tan Son Nhat to focus on domestic services.

While supporters, including the Civil Aviation Authority, cite benefits like easier management, reduced costs, and increased direct flights, experts voice significant concerns. The primary issue is the poor transport connectivity to Long Thanh, leading to inconvenience, increased travel time, costs, and potential delays for passengers from HCMC. Some argue Tan Son Nhat still has capacity, suggesting a gradual transition, possibly starting with cargo, as infrastructure improves. The Ministry of Construction is now assessing impacts and formulating a comprehensive transition roadmap.

KOLs were recognized as "digital ambassadors," integral to national progress by shaping public awareness and promoting Vietnam's identity.

A significant outcome was the launch of the "Digital Trust Alliance," uniting KOLs, businesses, and media to spread positive values, foster trust, and establish transparency standards online. This initiative underscores Vietnam's commitment to cultivating a trustworthy and accountable digital environment.

articles.title: Australia’s largest airline Qantas Airways to pay record fine of $58M for pandemic sackings
articles.summary:
Australia's largest airline, Qantas Airways, has been ordered to pay a record A$90 million ($58.64 million) fine for illegally sacking 1,800 ground staff during the Covid-19 pandemic. This penalty, the largest in Australian labor law history, was imposed by the Federal Court.

Judge Michael Lee criticized Qantas for its lack of genuine contrition and its litigation tactics, stating their regret seemed more about company damage than harm to workers. The Transport Workers' Union (TWU) brought the case, and A$50 million of the fine will go to them. This follows an earlier A$120 million compensation agreement for the sacked employees. The ruling sends a strong message that such violations are not acceptable as merely a "cost of doing business." Qantas has stated it will pay the fine and apologized.

articles.title: Tropical depression hits northern Vietnam, bringing heavy rain and strong winds
articles.summary:
A tropical depression made landfall along northern Vietnam's coast, near Quang Ninh and Hai Phong, bringing heavy rain, strong winds (up to 49 kph), and increased landslide risks. The system is moving west-northwest towards the Vietnam-China border, where it will weaken.

Northeastern and north-central provinces, including Thanh Hoa, Nghe An, and Quang Tri, face significant rainfall, potentially exceeding 300mm in some areas. Coastal regions and seas are experiencing hazardous conditions. Landslide warnings have been issued for 152 communes due to saturated soil. This is Vietnam's second storm this year; the previous one, Wipha, caused two deaths and damage. Authorities forecast up to seven storms by October, with three likely impacting mainland Vietnam.

Pfizer is actively supporting Vietnam's national healthcare transformation, aligning with the government's focus on science, technology, and healthcare reforms. General Director Darrell Oh outlined Pfizer's strategy, which includes a comprehensive "toolbox" of innovative vaccines, breakthrough treatments, and strategic partnerships.

The company addresses Vietnam's rising disease burdens, especially respiratory illnesses, by prioritizing preventive solutions, combating antimicrobial resistance, and expanding access to essential medicines. Pfizer enhances healthcare access through new therapies, policy advocacy, patient support programs, public-private collaborations, disease awareness campaigns, and talent development. They aim to help Vietnam leverage its "golden population" period to become an ASEAN pharmaceutical hub and elevate its healthcare system to global standards.

articles.title: Bangkok named best city for Gen Z
articles.summary:
According to a Time Out survey based on feedback from over 18,500 global residents, Bangkok has been named the world's best city for Gen Z (people in their 20s). The Thai capital's top ranking is attributed to a high happiness rate among young residents (84%), a strong sense of community with ease of making friends, affordability (71% found it budget-friendly), and vibrant nightlife.

Melbourne, Australia, secured second place, praised for its diversity, inclusivity, and thriving art and culture scene. Cape Town, South Africa, ranked third, noted for its beauty, happy residents, and affordable nights out. New York City came fourth for its excitement and nightlife, while Copenhagen rounded out the top five, scoring well for happiness and romance.

articles.summary: A British tourist, Alicia Kemp, 25, pleaded guilty to dangerous driving causing death while drunk on an e-scooter in Perth, Australia. The incident on May 31 led to the death of 51-year-old Thanh Phan and resulted in Kemp facing a maximum 20-year prison sentence.
